conversation:
Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have cleared your mind? I hunger for battle. We must find the sanctuary.
Player: The prisoner gave up his secrets.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Fezzerk: Stop! I give up! M-mercy, please!
Narrator: *The goblin's snivelling makes your blood boil. You could give in to the rage and end the wicked little maggot in one strike...*
Narrator: *...but perhaps he knows something useful? Your head aches as rage fights against reason.*
Player: Ignore the rage. Listen to your head. There is nothing to gain from being rash.
: True
Narrator: *The veil of rage wavers. Your blood seems to cool in your veins.*
Fezzerk: W-well, what do you say?
Fezzerk: I know things. If you let me live, I'll make it worth your while. I p-promise!
NodeContext: Scared, bargaining for this life.
Player: Run along, goblin. Before I change my mind.

Fist Marcus: Hello, Isobel.
InternalNodeContext: Marcus never vouched for the players. This is their first encounter with him.
Isobel: Marcus - is that you? What's happened to you?
Fist Marcus: I've been blessed. You can be too. Come with me and you can hear it all from Ketheric himself.
Player: What are you?
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: Probe his thoughts for more information.
: False
Narrator: *The man's mind burns with empty ecstasy, utterly enslaved by the Absolute. You can sense nothing else.*
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: You're going to meet Ketheric - face-to-face.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say.
Mizora: Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: Show me more.
Mizora: With pleasure. As long as you're willing to give in.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: What exactly will this entail?
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise.
Mizora: Let me show you.
Player: I can take it.
Mizora: I know you can, sister. You know just how much the Hells can hurt.
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen.
Mizora: Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war.
Mizora: Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Give it to me.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied.
Mizora: Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean.
Mizora: Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The polluted swamps of Minauros.
Narrator: *You inhale the oily clouds of Minauros' stink. It is the stench of dead lovers and sour romances. It is the unwantable - but you still lust for more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.
Mizora: To think how you've starved yourself up to this moment. To think how you chose the sweet over the bitter.
Mizora: One last choice, and starve no longer.
Mizora: Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.
Player: Nessus, where the Hells' overlord reigns supreme.
Narrator: *You are flush with untold power. You could rip apart mountains and bring gods to their knees. This is the ultimate you: the commander of planes, the director of fate.*

The player player rotates their palms upward, and look up, basking in the arcane sensory experience.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.

The flame circle kicks up higher, the player and Mizora float off of the ground.

Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?

Narrator: *A tingle runs through your head and down to your feet.*

Player: Confident. No tiny tadpole will be getting the best of me.
Wyll: Courage in danger's shadow. I love to see it.

Wyll: The tadpole's weakened me, suppressed greater talents. But beyond that -
Wyll: I've shown no sign of turning. No nausea, no pain, not even a hot flash.
Player: We could probably dig up some poison mushrooms, if you're that keen to be sick.

Ulma: Rech t i hathran roost.
NodeContext: REK tay ee HATH-ran ROOST
Narrator: *You recognise the funeral rites of the Gur people - the same monster hunters you met in the hag's swamp. Their leader is burning the possessions of those who have fallen.*
Ulma: Im orak ne tay. Krasin ne trah!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ulma pauses for a moment, staring at the fire in contemplation before she turns and walks over to the player.
Ulma: So, the impossible spawn walks among us in the blazing sun. We have been looking for you.
Astarion: And here I am. What do you want?
Ulma: The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future.
Gandrel: When I was hunting you, I was to bring you back here. To interrogate you, discover how to save our children, and then destroy you.
Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed.
Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: What does it matter to you?
Ulma: It matters because you are the last hope to rescue our little ones from Cazador Szarr.
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: And if I decline to help?
Ulma: Then we can all see what you really are. At best, a coward. At worst, a monster.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: Rise up in unison - they can't stop you all.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Even if we did somehow unshackle our collars simultaneously, and overthrow our oppressors, there would be consequences.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Lorna Esthelian: You haven't seen him, have you? Pale, skinny - extremely piercing eyes.

Lorna Esthelian: Normal. Mostly. Didn't have much of an appetite at dinner, though he said he was saving himself for tonight.
Lorna Esthelian: He was so enthusiastic. I don't understand why he hasn't shown up...

Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Who exactly are you?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel grimaces in anger, but remains silent
Vlaakith: Who... am... I?
Vlaakith: I am Vlaakith. Undying Queen of the noble githyanki. God Regent of the Six Arms of Tu'narath.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith gains her composure and motions everyone to rise. Everyone present rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: You have ventured far from your kind's comforts to serve us.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Sa'varsh Kethk: K'chakhi! We are training to fight ghaik. You think they will hesitate?
NodeContext: Angry, has been beating him, posturing for the class
Youth Varrl: They won't need to, if we keep killing each other for them! It's - it's stupid! Orph-
Sa'varsh Kethk: Silence! It seems your childish prattling is attracting an audience.
NodeContext: Teacher finally acnowledges the player
Sa'varsh Kethk: You fight again. This time, daggers only. And to the death as instructed.
Sa'varsh Kethk: Who wants to challenge this snivelling is'tark?

Sa'varsh Kethk: An interesting proposition.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player picks up a dagger (can be from floor, rack - cinematic preference)

Youth Varrl: I - I refuse. There has to be a better way -
Sa'varsh Kethk: G'lyck. Kill him, and put us all out of our misery.
Player: The boy's naivety is pathetic. Kill him.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I'm a True Soul. I saw them through Nere's eyes.
Apprentice Laridda: You - you can do that? I mean of course. Of course, True Soul.
Apprentice Laridda: Th-thank you for sharing, truly.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Karlach: Some firepower'll help bust open that wall. Then we can free the poor lads inside.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.

Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?

Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.

Kith'rak Voss: It is not.
Kith'rak Voss: I've heard word from Crche Y'llek. You are infected - yet the one in the Prism has chosen you, protects you with their power.
Kith'rak Voss: The Prism's tenant alone has the power to end Vlaakith's tyranny.
Kith'rak Voss: I've sought their freedom for aeons. When the Prism went missing, I feared the worst.
Kith'rak Voss: Instead, you've granted the opportunity I've so long awaited.
Kith'rak Voss: All that remains is the key that unchains them - and I've found someone who I believe can provide it.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring the Prism to Baldur's Gate. I'll be waiting in a taproom called Sharess' Caress. That is where we decide the fate of my people.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.

Ulma: The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future.
Gandrel: When I was hunting you, I was to bring you back here. To interrogate you, discover how to save our children, and then destroy you.
Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed.
Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Somewhat. It's... complicated.
Ulma: Then I shall make things simple. You stole our little ones from us - can you steal them back from your master?
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: You think you can guilt me into doing what you're too weak to?
Ulma: We offer you a chance, perhaps your final chance, to heal just some of the pain you have caused.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: All right, I'll do what I can.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Let's kill her.
Shadowheart: First I need answers.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: Such cruelty...
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.

Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?

GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.

Kith'rak Voss: Ska'kek kir Gith shabell'eth. My blade rests. Mother Gith compels you to listen.
Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.
Kith'rak Voss: Within it lies the seed of Vlaakith's demise. And I intend to help you bring it to fruition.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith's demise? Shka'keth. I should run you through for suggesting it.
Player: Vlaakith is my queen. Why would I want to end her?
Kith'rak Voss: Because her throne rests on lies, more than a hundred gish scholars could count in a lifetime. I will share but two.
Lae'zel: No. I don't believe it.
Kith'rak Voss: Your doubt does not make it any less true, child.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.

Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?

Player: I saw one of your officers acting suspiciously near that chest.
: True
Manip Bakshi: That's impossible. Reynash was on duty the whole -
Manip Bakshi: That sneaky little git. It was him all along?
Player: Don't be too hard on him. He was scared and missing home.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I'm a True Soul. I saw them through Nere's eyes.
Apprentice Laridda: You - you can do that? I mean of course. Of course, True Soul.
Apprentice Laridda: Th-thank you for sharing, truly.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Shadowheart: Sounds like an unnecessary risk to me. Though that hasn't stopped us before.
Player: I'll do what I can.

Narrator: *Hollow eyes, pale gums - this beast isn't angry, he's starving.*
Player: Here, eat this.

Lora: My daughter's name is Vanra. We were in the Blushing Mermaid when she went missing.
Blaze Liara Portyr: Madam, tell me... you said... she was... ah... taken from a tavern?
NodeContext: struggling to get the words out - the memory is there but she just can't reach it
: True
Narrator: *You catch the barest tendrils of magic coiled around the Flaming Fist.*
Lora: Yes. The Blushing. Mermaid. Down by the docks. I've told you a hundred times - why aren't you listening?
Player: Examine the Flaming Fist.
: True
Narrator: *Someone, or something, has tampered with her memory.*
Blaze Liara Portyr: What, ah, what were we discussing?
Lora: What is happening? I feel like I'm going mad.
Player: Someone's tampered with the Flaming Fist's memory.
Blaze Liara Portyr: Nonsense. I'm fine. Madam, tell me why you're... urgh... here, and I will assist.
Lora: Gods, you're right. Something's wrong with her.
Lora: Can you help me? I've no family, and Vanra's father isn't around. The Flaming Fist were my last resort.
Lora: I'm so afraid. And so tired. I've been looking night and day, everywhere I could.
Player: I'll help you find your daughter.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: What's going on here?
He Who Was: You walk in the darkness, unafraid? How curious.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
: True
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Depends. Who murdered this woman?
He Who Was: She is not the victim. Nay, she is the perpetrator.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: Her soul has departed for the Fugue Plane, to be judged or lost forever. What more could she pay?
He Who Was: The Fugue Plane is no obstacle to one such as I.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Why would you do that?
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player wakes up in a middle of a night because the owlbear cub approaches it
Narrator: *You recognise the feathered creature - it's the owlbear cub you rescued.*
Owlbear Cub: *Hoo. Hoo-hoot.*
NodeContext: Curious, but cautious.
Player: Wait for him to approach you.
: True
Narrator: *The cub tilts his head. He does not trust you - yet.*
Player: Fetch a piece of food from your bag.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: I am surprised, Astarion. I thought you'd jump at a chance like this.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: Her house, Oblodra, was infamous for experimenting with mind flayers. Could her blood be tainted somehow?
Astarion: That would explain the stench, yes.
Astarion: I already have enough illithid filth in my head - I don't want it in my stomach as well.
Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.
Player: Don't do anything you don't want to.
Astarion: All right. Thank you.

Ettvard Needle: Well, well, if it isn't the city's next celebrity! You star in our next edition's top story.
Player: How long is this article? Because I've got a lot of stories - and I only blow up in some of them.
Ettvard Needle: We have plenty of ink. Enough to cover all your misadventures in this good city.
Ettvard Needle: Since your arrival, reports of Absolutist activity in this city have increased tenfold. Hardly seems a coincidence.
Ettvard Needle: The truth will be out with tomorrow's broadsheet. People will spit in your face. Your very presence will be bad for business. You'll be a pariah. An outcast. As you should be.
Ettvard Needle: And then we can only hope the Fist do their duty and escort you to the gallows! Your days scumming up this good city's streets will be over.
Player: This letter proving you're Gortash's puppet would make a better headline.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?

Gondian Zanner Toobin: What? Go away.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: It's worth the risk - worst case scenario, you die fighting.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: If it were only our lives on the line, we'd have rebelled long ago.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: There's always a way. Will you fight back if I free your families?

Lord Delwaer Jeth: Oh good. An audience come to witness your stupidity.
Sir Gorran Penghyst: Stop trying to distract me, and prepare yourself. We begin on my say!

Sir Gorran Penghyst: Because - because - that's not the point! You sold me a fake, and you're going to pay for it. If not in gold, then in blood!

Danis: I know you - you're from the grove.
Danis: Blessed gods - you were with the Absolute this whole time.
Player: Shh. The other tieflings sent me - they're safe.
Danis: ...Bex is alive? Oh, thank the gods. Thank you.
Danis: When I woke up and she wasn't here I thought the worst.
Danis: We're dead if we don't get out of here. I can't believe Zevlor wanted us to go with these zealots.
Player: Don't worry, I'm going to get you out of here.

Wyll: Question for you: have you ever heard a banshee's scream?
Player: No, but I once made one whimper a bit.
Wyll: Yes, well - ahem. If you'd ever actually heard one, you'd not heard a whimper, but a wail.
Wyll: Loud enough to wake the dead, and shrill enough to shatter a golden goblet.
Wyll: I thought it the most terrible noise in all sixteen planes. But there's one even more fearsome than that.
Player: What is it?
Wyll: The doubt in our minds crying out for attention.
Wyll: 'It's hopeless', it says. 'Stop resisting. Give up and give in.'
Wyll: Doubt is the greatest villain we face. Greater than all the Hells' devils, greater than a murderous god.
Wyll: Most people don't find it so easy to conquer. It's a good thing for us that we aren't 'most people'.
Wyll: Slay your doubt, and nothing can stop you. Not a demon, not a dragon, and certainly not an illithid worm.
Wyll: I'm glad to see you're not one to give up.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.
: True
Narrator: *Her smirk hides her intent - she's toying with you.*
Player: I'm Ketheric's new favourite.
: False
The Warden: Hm. Fascinating.
The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Figaro...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: If it had been the dwarf alone, we might have stood a chance, but these doppelgangers... they swarmed us.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: We were paralysed before we even had the chance to fight back.
Player: I'm glad I could keep you safe.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: And I'm glad you're fighting the fight to keep the Dread Lord out of the city.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I was on my way to the Upper City when I heard a commotion. I stepped in to see if I could help.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's not every day you have the chance to catch a killer in action. Not even in this profession.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You, on the other hand, you've probably seen your fair share of murders since you discovered your heritage.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The assailant is dead now. But I overheard some of his plans.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It offers access to the 'tribunal'. An initiation rite, held by your Father's acolytes, that brings a new cultist into the fold.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Perhaps they've even asked you to undertake this gruesome sacrament.
Player: I killed Bhaal's second favourite child, Orin.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So the Bhaalists had a new leader, and you killed them...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: This is excellent news. Though - perhaps not as excellent as you might imagine.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You see, when one cult leader is ousted, all that does is leave a vacuum for the next one to step in.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: My best guess says it's whoever runs the tribunal - a Bhaalist ritual of initiation. It's all Dolor could talk about.
Player: Where can I find this tribunal?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The dwarf mentioned somewhere called 'Candulhallow's Tombstones'.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I would look into it myself... if it wouldn't get me fired.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

NodeContext: Speak with dead style

He Who Was: She is not the victim. Nay, she is the perpetrator.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: She's dead - how much more can she pay?
He Who Was: Death is not the end - merely another beginning.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Why would you do that?
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Nightsong: Balthazar has drawn his final rancid breath. A pity it was not my hand that brought it about. Instead, it was you.
InternalNodeContext: This node if Balthazar was attacked in a scene just before this one.
Nightsong: You, who have come to find the wicked favour of your goddess. Go on - show me your dagger, your sword, your knife.
Narrator: *Your worship of Lady Shar, out in the open at last. You managed to keep the secret from those around you for so long... but no more.*
Shar: My spear, child - pierce her heart, and become my sword hand. My Dark Justiciar.
Nightsong: Well, well, well. What's that I sense? A spear intended for my heart. Empowered by your goddess, aye - empowered to kill the child of a god.
NodeContext: Slight cock of her head, as if sensing something that is not yet visible.
Nightsong: There is much your mistress does not tell you - my death will come at a terrible price. One that you will not grasp until it is too late.
Nightsong: Do you know what I am, little assassin? For I know you - a lost child, frightened by wolves in the dark.
Shadowheart: What did you just say...?
Nightsong: Much has been promised to you, hasn't it? But what has been taken from you? What do you know of your own heart - your own life?
Nightsong: I sense more in you than you know. Why?
Shar: Do not listen, Shadowheart. She seeks to distract, to confuse, to prolong her ugly existence and deny you your destiny. Shut out her words.
NodeContext: Reassuring and soothing, yet with an edge beneath the surface. (urging Shadowheart to sacrifice someone)
Nightsong: Shar speaks now, doesn't she? Dribbles the poison of oblivion in the shell of your ear? I do not hear her words, but I sense her rage.

Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

Ettvard Needle: Well, well, if it isn't the city's next celebrity! You star in our next edition's top story.
Player: Yeah - I heard all about your article, and I want you to shut it down.
Ettvard Needle: Well, you should've considered that before disgracing yourself in public.
Ettvard Needle: We have plenty of ink. Enough to cover all your misadventures in this good city.
Ettvard Needle: Trafficking refugees into our city is hardly a good look. Especially when so many are Absolutists and murderers.
Ettvard Needle: The truth will be out with tomorrow's broadsheet. People will spit in your face. Your very presence will be bad for business. You'll be a pariah. An outcast. As you should be.
Ettvard Needle: And then we can only hope the Fist do their duty and escort you to the gallows! Your days scumming up this good city's streets will be over.
Player: This letter proving you're Gortash's puppet would make a better headline.

Boney: Browse our bespoke Stoney and Boney creations, or commission a statue in your likeness. It is our most sought-after service.

Isobel: Aylin.
NodeContext: holding back a sob - disbelieving
Nightsong: Isobel.
NodeContext: also disbelieving. Aylin is unsteady on her feet. She's been through 100 years of torment, fought Ketheric Thorm, and now she's seeing the love of her life, who she thought dead.
Nightsong: My love... you were dead. I saw your body...
NodeContext: to the ground. Aylin falls to her knees, weakened by battle and disbelief
Isobel: I'm here. A-and so are you. And my father, he - he can't hurt us any longer.
NodeContext: Chokes up on 'my father, he - '. Still generally disbelieving.
Nightsong: I dreamt every night that you'd come back to me. That somehow it was all a nightmare dawn would undo.
NodeContext: On 'come back to me,' Aylin breaks the embrace and looks into Isobel's eyes. We want to feign contact here (cinematic constraint) while still maintaining closeness/ implying hand-holding. CC Greg
Isobel: I had no dreams at all. Nothing but darkness. And when I awoke, my father said you were dead.
NodeContext: mirthless humor - reflecting on the bleak reality
Nightsong: His soul was poisoned by the god of death. His sick devotion ruined him.
Nightsong: But for all his sins, he brought you back to me. Are you all right?
NodeContext: She leans back, looking into Isobel's eyes, searching them.
Isobel: I will be. And you?
Nightsong: In this moment, I want for nothing.
NodeContext: with a smile
Isobel: Ah! It's you, isn't it? You're the talk of this place, you know. I'm Isobel, and this is -
Nightsong: We have met. The instigator of my despair - and then my elation.
Nightsong: We must watch this one closely, Isobel. Their motivations are suspect - aye, suspect indeed.
Isobel: Hmm - it sounds like we have much to discuss. Perhaps we could join you in your camp later?
Isobel: I have more to thank you for than I knew. And we have much to discuss. Perhaps we could join you in your camp later?
Player: Firstly, allow me to apologise to Dame Aylin. My actions were strategy - not personal.

Brem: Something I can help you with?
Brem: Well now! If we're talking, my guess is you've got coin to spend.
Player: I'm here to buy your prisoner.
Brem: I doubt you've got that kinda dosh lying about. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Pay him.
Brem: He's all yours. Don't forget to feed him - he bawls something proper.

Lorna Esthelian: Ah - a friendly face at last. Are you going to the party as well?
Player: A party in the sewers?
Lorna Esthelian: I know. Bit strange, isn't it? But then you have to be open to trying new things.
Lorna Esthelian: The venue's called 'The Palace'. Not sure what it stands for, but it sounds very exclusive.
Lorna Esthelian: My date's supposed to meet me here, but there's no sign of him.
Lorna Esthelian: You haven't seen him, have you? Pale, skinny - extremely piercing eyes.
Lorna Esthelian: Looks a bit like you, actually.
Lorna Esthelian: It's funny. He was ever so keen for me to come. He didn't seem the type to cancel...
Player: Did he say what kind of party it's supposed to be?
Lorna Esthelian: Only that it was him and a few of his closest friends. Said he couldn't wait to introduce me to them - how often does a man say that to a girl he's only met once?
Lorna Esthelian: He was so enthusiastic. I don't understand why he hasn't shown up...
Player: You've had a very lucky escape. Your date was a vampire.

Wyll: Question for you: have you ever heard a banshee's scream?
Player: No, but I once made one whimper a bit.
Wyll: Yes, well - ahem. If you'd ever actually heard one, you'd not heard a whimper, but a wail.
Wyll: Loud enough to wake the dead, and shrill enough to shatter a golden goblet.
Wyll: I thought it the most terrible noise in all sixteen planes. But there's one even more fearsome than that.
Player: Lae'zel's tenacious battle-cries?
Wyll: Not even close. I find them comforting, even. What I'm thinking of is far more malicious:
Wyll: The doubt in our minds crying out for attention.
Wyll: 'It's hopeless', it says. 'Stop resisting. Give up and give in.'
Wyll: Doubt is the greatest villain we face. Greater than all the Hells' devils, greater than a murderous god.
Wyll: Most people don't find it so easy to conquer. It's a good thing for us that we aren't 'most people'.
Wyll: Slay your doubt, and nothing can stop you. Not a demon, not a dragon, and certainly not an illithid worm.
Wyll: I'm glad to see you're not one to give up.

Narrator: *A tingle runs through your head and down to your feet.*
Wyll: Ah, there it is - that shiver. Our little brain-worms have made fast friends, it would seem.
Wyll: How do you feel?
Player: I'm more interested in how you feel.
Wyll: Healthy. And troubled by that fact.
Wyll: Before the illithids' unscheduled surgery, I'd felled hundreds of beasts and a fair few fiends.
Wyll: The tadpole's weakened me, suppressed greater talents. But beyond that -
Wyll: I've shown no sign of turning. No nausea, no pain, not even a hot flash.
Player: It makes no sense, I know. Why haven't we turned?

Varsh Ko'kuu: I don't have time to parent you as well. What do you want now?
Player: Let me help - I can take it somewhere safe.
: True
: True
Varsh Ko'kuu: You? What do you know about githyanki child-rearing?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Still, the captain's due for an inspection any day now, and if she sees it here...
NodeContext: the captain will destroy his precious egg if she finds it
Varsh Ko'kuu: Tell me, what will you do with it if I entrust it to you?
Player: I'll raise it as if it were my own flesh and blood.

Sovereign Glut: ((*it is time. we take death to the duergar*))
Player: It's already done - the duergar are dead.
Sovereign Glut: ((*here, I break ground. from the dark will a mighty Circle rise. my song will fill the Grotto!*))
Sovereign Glut: ((*death-doer - the Grotto may sustain but one Sovereign. in the Age of Glut...*))
Sovereign Glut: ((*...there may be no Spaw. eliminate the other Sovereign*))
Player: I'll have no part of this.

Narrator: *Hollow eyes, pale gums - this beast isn't angry, he's starving.*
Player: I don't have any food for you, but I will be back - I promise.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I'm a True Soul. I saw them through Nere's eyes.
Apprentice Laridda: You - you can do that? I mean of course. Of course, True Soul.
Apprentice Laridda: Th-thank you for sharing, truly.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: High-powered explosives do sound fun, but must we waste them saving lives?
Player: I'll do what I can.

Slack-Skinned Head: My head hurts...
Slack-Skinned Head: Can I go back to bed, mummy?
Player: Well this is deeply unsettling.
Slack-Skinned Head: I don't know what that means...
Slack-Skinned Head: I had the dream again. The big spiky snail that came from the sky.
Slack-Skinned Head: I'm sleepy, mummy. You must stop waking me up.
Slack-Skinned Head: I'm just very sleepy, mummy... I wish you'd stop waking me up so much.
Player: Time to go back to sleep, then. Good night... you.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Figaro...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: If it had been the dwarf alone, we might have stood a chance, but these doppelgangers... they swarmed us.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: We were paralysed before we even had the chance to fight back.
Player: I'm glad I could keep you safe.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: And I'm glad you're fighting the fight to keep the Dread Lord out of the city.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I was on my way to the Upper City when I heard a commotion. I stepped in to see if I could help.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's not every day you have the chance to catch a killer in action. Not even in this profession.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You, on the other hand, you've probably seen your fair share of murders since you discovered your heritage.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The assailant is dead now. But I overheard some of his plans.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It offers access to the 'tribunal'. An initiation rite, held by your Father's acolytes, that brings a new cultist into the fold.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Perhaps they've even asked you to undertake this gruesome sacrament.
Player: I killed Bhaal's second favourite child, Orin.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So the Bhaalists had a new leader, and you killed them...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: This is excellent news. Though - perhaps not as excellent as you might imagine.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You see, when one cult leader is ousted, all that does is leave a vacuum for the next one to step in.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: My best guess says it's whoever runs the tribunal - a Bhaalist ritual of initiation. It's all Dolor could talk about.
Player: Let me guess - you want me to investigate.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: If it were up to me, I'd have every Fist in the city on this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The dwarf mentioned somewhere called 'Candulhallow's Tombstones'. But I can't even look into it... not without getting fired.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I would look into it myself... if it wouldn't get me fired.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.
: True
Narrator: *Her smirk hides her intent - she's toying with you.*
Player: I'm not here to play games - I need to speak to the prisoners. Now.
The Warden: That tone might work on swaddled babes and puppies, but I am neither, True Soul.
The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.
Player: How about a large donation? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
The Warden: I'm afraid none, no matter how generous, may speak to the prisoners.
The Warden: The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.
Player: I should have seen that coming.

Big Huido: Mate, what part of 'Guild business' isn't getting through that stone-skull of yours?
Big Huido: Whoa, whoa, mate - this is the last place you need to be. Clear off, yeah?
Player: Why can't I be here?
Big Huido: Two words - Guild business. Only an idiot gets between them and their shipments.
Player: You didn't hear? I'm the new Guild representative. I've been dying to get my hands on that shipment.

Akabi: YOU THIEF. YOU CHEATED.
Player: HOW DOES IT FEEL, SUCKER?

Wulbren Bongle: Your friend is some smooth talker to shut a guard down like that. What do you lot want with me, exactly?
Wulbren Bongle: You ordered that guard about as if you were the Absolute herself. What do you want with us, exactly?

Wulbren Bongle: Huh. And why would you be so inclined?
Player: Barcus told me you were here, and asked me to help.

GROUP_Emperors: Did you not hear me? I said TURN BACK.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel steps forward, confident.
Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?
Kith'rak Voss: I've not come to kill you, Lae'zel. I've come to aid you.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] Voss kneels and lays his sword on the ground in the githyanki sign of submission.
Kith'rak Voss: Ska'kek kir Gith shabell'eth. My blade rests. Mother Gith compels you to listen.
Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.
Kith'rak Voss: Within it lies the seed of Vlaakith's demise. And I intend to help you bring it to fruition.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith's demise? Shka'keth. I should run you through for suggesting it.
Player: I'm not giving you the Astral Prism, if that's what you're wanting.
Kith'rak Voss: It is not.
Kith'rak Voss: I've heard word from Crche Y'llek. You are infected - yet the one in the Prism has chosen you, protects you with their power.
Kith'rak Voss: The Prism's tenant alone has the power to end Vlaakith's tyranny.
Kith'rak Voss: I've sought their freedom for aeons. When the Prism went missing, I feared the worst.
Kith'rak Voss: Instead, you've granted the opportunity I've so long awaited.
Kith'rak Voss: All that remains is the key that unchains them - and I've found someone who I believe can provide it.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring the Prism to Baldur's Gate. I'll be waiting in a taproom called Sharess' Caress. That is where we decide the fate of my people.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.
Player: What do you want to do Lae'zel? I have your back.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Make it quick.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: She's just trying to rile you up.
Shadowheart: I know. But she's not lying. She made me in her image.
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.

Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.

The party travels with the submersible to the underwater Iron Throne building. A lightbeam spotlights the water in front of the submersible, seeing nothing but murky water until the Iron Throne comes into view - a ruined, submerged multi-storey building, topped by new, domed construction.

Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Omeluum: Halt.
Narrator: *A cold, suckering wetness grasps at your mind. A voice, familiar to you from the Underdark, wraps itself around your brain.*
Omeluum: You have arrived at an optimal time. Collapse is imminent, and there are hostages in need of aid.
Player: Tell me how to find them.
Player: Tell me what to do.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me you'd be, gith.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: What's wrong? You seem different than before.
Shadowheart: No questions! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Lae'zel: The ravings of a lunatic. Strike her down.
: True
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Keep your hands away from that blade.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You can't kill me just because some 'whispers' told you to.
Shadowheart: I can't see anything else! I can't shake it.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: You're exhausted - not thinking straight. You need to rest.
: True
Shadowheart: Rest where? I can't leave. The whispers won't let me leave.
Player: You can stay here. I'll watch over you.

Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have cleared your mind? I hunger for battle. We must find the sanctuary.
Player: The prisoner gave up his secrets.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: No. This ends now, and so do you.
Nightwarden Minthara: You would dare...? Guards - to me!

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel kneeling at corpse
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel gets up
Isobel: What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. I sensed the tadpole in his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: I have no reason to lie. Marcus was a danger to you all.
: True
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude.
Isobel: You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I may be a True Soul, but I'm not like Marcus. The parasite doesn't control me.
Isobel: If I didn't believe it before, I certainly do now.
Isobel: Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell.
Isobel: Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|
Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect.
Isobel: It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The party approaches a mind flayer pod. Inside is the half-devil Mizora, Wyll's patron. She pushes her hands against the transparent cover and smiles. Next to the pod is a console with two buttons on it, the 'unleash' and 'annihilate' buttons on the console in the tutorial.
Mizora: Now enough sniffing around and get me out of this thing.
Narrator: *Your eyes turn to the control panel next to the pod. It has two devices marked with illithid symbols.*
Narrator: *The controls are open to your tadpole's command - to your authority.*
Player: SMASH THE POD.
: True
[description] CinematicNodeContext: [reuse]  The player's fist slams against the pod and it cracks open.

Mizora steps out of the pod.

Mizora steps out of the pod.
Mizora: Good work. I'd give you a gold star, but I'm fresh out.

Sergeant Thrinn: I'll be damned. Nere's gone and kicked it.
Sergeant Thrinn: Listen, you pricks. Grab your gear and get ready to move.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Sergeant Thrinn: Death-curse be damned, we're heading to Moonrise.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Sergeant Thrinn: It's time I met the General in the flesh.
Player: What about the slaves? What happens to them?
Sergeant Thrinn: What else? They're coming with us. A gift to the General from his new faithful.
Wyll: Speak up, chief. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: The gnomes won't survive the curse. What good is a gift of corpses?
Sergeant Thrinn: Shit - you're on to something, hate to say.
Sergeant Thrinn: Get out of here, squat-pricks - before I toss you all in the fires.

Player: Good idea. They will make a fine offering.
Sergeant Thrinn: Yes. They will serve the Absolute's Chosen.
Wyll: Your heart made of stone? They deserved freedom - and you denied it.
Sergeant Thrinn: It's time I met the General in the flesh.
Player: I am freeing these gnomes. Just try and stop me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Is this my fate - to be freed from Gortash's hell only to be trapped in yours?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: It is exactly what I think.
Player: Wyll pulled you from death's grip, and this is how you thank him?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You want my gratitude? Fine - take your fill. But I will not celebrate this infernal resurrection.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.*
Narrator: *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but -
Duke Ulder Ravengard: - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: Waking a dragon doesn't sound like a good idea.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is no ordinary dragon.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Player: 'Abi, diabole, et nunquam redi.'
Mizora: Ha. Haha. Hahahahahaha!
Mizora: I'll be damned. You want to free the pup from his pact.
Mizora: And you thought that idiotic display would do it? Bravo!
Mizora: Fine, I'll play your game. But I amend the pact once I'm freed - not before.
